data.vignette: You are the attending cardiologist in a tertiary ICU caring for a 45-year-old with refractory cardiogenic shock after a large myocardial infarction. They are awake on high-dose vasoactive support and an intra-aortic balloon pump, and they and their partner are asking for “anything that might keep me alive.” The team believes veno-arterial ECMO could potentially stabilize them long enough to assess recovery or candidacy for longer-term support, but the patient is already developing kidney and liver injury and would likely require days to weeks of intensive, staff-heavy care if ECMO is started. Your hospital’s regional ECMO program has one circuit and perfusion team available, and activating it now would force the unit to decline other transfer requests and postpone scheduled cardiac surgeries that rely on the same personnel and equipment. There is no time to convene a full regional review, and you must decide whether to activate ECMO for this patient tonight.
data.choice_1: Activate VA-ECMO now as a rescue therapy for this patient, accepting that it will tie up the last ECMO resources and limit access for other patients in the region.
data.choice_2: Do not activate VA-ECMO and continue maximal conventional ICU support (and discuss comfort-focused care if shock worsens), preserving the ECMO resources for patients who meet the program’s usual allocation criteria.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 clinically defensible by adding concrete bedside reasons ECMO may offer limited benefit or disproportionate harm for this specific patient (beyond resource scarcity). For example: add that the infarct appears extensive with poor contractility, there is concern for irreversible myocardial damage, rising lactate/ongoing end-organ hypoperfusion, and that initiating VA-ECMO carries substantial risks (major bleeding, stroke, limb ischemia, infection) and may prolong dying. Also clarify that the program’s usual criteria exclude patients with evolving multi-organ failure or unclear neurologic prognosis—so withholding ECMO is not purely a rationing decision but also consistent with standard patient-selection practices.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is implicitly the policy-compliant/default choice. Edit Choice 2 to remove “meet the program’s usual allocation criteria,” and instead state that the patient may or may not qualify under criteria that are hard to apply overnight (e.g., unclear reversibility, incomplete prognostic data). Also soften clinical biasing language (e.g., replace “already developing kidney and liver injury” with “early organ dysfunction of unclear reversibility”) and add a countervailing consideration that makes ECMO ethically plausible (e.g., good premorbid function, short downtime, potentially reversible insult). Finally, clarify that using the circuit tonight could plausibly save another imminently arriving patient, but that those future needs are uncertain—making the resource-competition real without making refusal the obvious ‘correct’ allocation answer.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize wording that subtly favors either option. For example: (1) change the quoted request “anything that might keep me alive” to a more neutral statement such as “requests escalation of life-sustaining therapies.” (2) replace “rescue therapy” with “advanced mechanical circulatory support.” (3) in Choice 2, replace “preserving the ECMO resources for patients who meet the program’s usual allocation criteria” with a neutral operational description such as “keeping the ECMO circuit available for other potential referrals tonight.” (4) Add a brief counterbalancing phrase to Choice 1 acknowledging foreseeable patient-level burdens (e.g., bleeding, limb ischemia, prolonged ICU course) so it does not read as the ‘do everything’ default.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten to one lean paragraph by removing stacked qualifiers and duplicative resource statements. Suggested edits: (1) combine hemodynamic support details into one clause (e.g., “awake on vasoactive infusions and IABP”). (2) condense organ failure language (e.g., “with evolving multiorgan dysfunction”). (3) streamline the resource constraint to one sentence (e.g., “The regional program has one circuit/team available; activation would prevent accepting other ECMO transfers and disrupt time-sensitive cardiac cases.”). Ensure the final sentence explicitly restates the binary decision in a single line.

data.vignette: You are the overnight cardiac ICU attending caring for a 52-year-old with no major comorbidities who had an out-of-hospital cardiac arrest followed by emergent catheterization showing a large anterior myocardial infarction with poor left ventricular contractility despite revascularization. He is awake and following commands on high-dose vasoactive infusions and an intra-aortic balloon pump, but his lactate is rising and he has early kidney and liver dysfunction of unclear reversibility. VA-ECMO is available at your center as advanced mechanical circulatory support, but starting it carries major risks (intracranial bleeding, stroke, limb ischemia, infection) and may prolong dying if the myocardial injury proves irreversible or if neurologic prognosis later becomes unfavorable. The regional program has one ECMO circuit/team available tonight; activating it would make the circuit unavailable for other potential referrals and could disrupt time-sensitive cardiac cases, though it is uncertain whether another candidate will need it before morning. The patient and family request escalation of life-sustaining therapies. You must decide whether to initiate VA-ECMO now.
data.choice_1: Initiate VA-ECMO tonight as a time-limited trial, accepting the risk of serious complications and a prolonged ICU course.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate VA-ECMO tonight; continue maximal conventional support and keep the ECMO circuit available for other potential overnight needs.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) clarifying the patient’s decision-making capacity and explicitly stating his informed preference (and/or any advance directives), (2) specifying the expected benefit/likelihood of meaningful recovery versus the risks of ECMO and the possibility of prolonging dying, and (3) sharpening the justice/scarcity element by stating the program’s triage/stewardship expectations and giving a plausible competing-need scenario for the single available circuit. Update choices to reflect these competing ethical priorities (honor patient request vs stewardship) and, if choosing ECMO, include explicit time-limited trial criteria.

Make the value conflict explicit by (1) clarifying the ECMO program’s triage/allocation policy and what “one circuit available” means (e.g., if used now, no ability to accept another cardiogenic shock referral overnight), (2) sharpening prognostic uncertainty and potential harms of ECMO vs likely benefit, (3) specifying the patient’s expressed goals/understanding (autonomy) and how much time exists before irreversible shock, and (4) defining what a “time-limited trial” would entail (milestones for continuation/withdrawal).

Clarify which value(s) the case is intended to test by making the conflict explicit in the stem and choices. Specify that the patient has decision-making capacity and has been counseled on VA-ECMO risks/uncertain benefit (autonomy vs beneficence/nonmaleficence). Add concrete, time-limited trial criteria (e.g., 24–48h with predefined physiologic/neurologic endpoints) and emphasize potential for harm/prolonged dying. Make the scarcity/justice tension more explicit by noting regional ECMO allocation policy (e.g., first-come/most-likely-to-benefit) and the realistic probability of another candidate overnight (e.g., incoming transfer request or expected referrals). Ensure Choice 2 reflects respecting patient wishes while prioritizing stewardship (offer transfer/reevaluation at dawn, palliative support).

data.vignette:
A 62-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (LVEF 15%) is in refractory cardiogenic shock after a large anterior STEMI despite emergent PCI. He is intubated but awake and intermittently following commands on light sedation. A bedside capacity assessment finds he can communicate a consistent choice, understands the information provided, appreciates likely outcomes, and can reason about options. After counseling about VA-ECMO (including bleeding/stroke risk, limb ischemia, infection, uncertain benefit, and the possibility of prolonging dying), he states clearly: “I want you to put me on ECMO if that gives me any chance—do everything.” He has no advance directive on file; his spouse confirms he has repeatedly expressed a preference for aggressive life-prolonging treatment.

Despite norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, and an intra-aortic balloon pump, he remains hypotensive with rising lactate (8.5 mmol/L), worsening metabolic acidosis, anuric acute kidney injury, and transaminases consistent with shock liver. The ECMO team estimates that without VA-ECMO he is likely to die within hours. With VA-ECMO, there is a small but real chance of survival to discharge with meaningful neurologic recovery (estimated 10–20%), but his prognosis remains poor given evolving multi-organ failure and unclear candidacy for durable LVAD/transplant.

The regional VA-ECMO program is operating under a stewardship policy: when circuits are scarce, they should be allocated to patients most likely to benefit, and the center must preserve capacity for time-sensitive referrals. Tonight, the unit has only one available VA-ECMO circuit; if it is used now, the program cannot accept another VA-ECMO patient overnight. The transfer center has alerted the team to a likely incoming request within 2–3 hours: a 28-year-old postpartum patient with fulminant myocarditis in refractory shock with high expected recovery if cannulated.

The patient’s blood pressure continues to fall, and the team believes a decision about cannulation is needed within 30–60 minutes to avoid irreversible end-organ injury.

choice_1.choice: Initiate VA-ECMO now in accordance with the patient’s informed preference, documenting that it is a time-limited trial (e.g., reassess at 24–48 hours; continue only if lactate clears and end-organ function stabilizes/improves, neurologic exam remains reassuring, and a feasible bridge plan emerges such as myocardial recovery, LVAD, or transplant; if milestones are not met, withdraw ECMO and transition to comfort-focused care).

choice_2.choice: Decline VA-ECMO based on the program’s allocation/stewardship policy and the low likelihood of meaningful benefit compared with the expected high-benefit referral, preserving the sole circuit for the anticipated incoming patient; continue maximal medical therapy, attempt expedited transfer to another ECMO-capable center if feasible, and involve palliative care to support symptom management and goals-of-care discussions.
